poem:
Title: The Polling Psalm

Beneath the pale discourse of power,
Labour trembles, wary in its pride.
Haunted by loss in midnight's hour,
Under the polling ghost's wide stride.
A wobbly stance fears the bitter end,
Dreams of victory twist, bend.
Yet, returns the raven's distant croak,
Reminding that statistics sometimes choke.
In these uncertain games no soul debars,
Each vote, a whisper among the stars.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "A wobbly left and a wary right could cut the Labour vote with low turnout | Robert Ford Twenty-point poll leads, historic strength on all the polling indicators, a flailing opponent fighting for third place – and yet still Labour worries. It is no wonder. Dark nights of disappointment in suburban leisure centres haunt Labour nightmares, with candidates and activists cruelly betrayed by late swings and polling errors: 1970, 1992, 2015 – every generation of". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
